item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.

item.title: About me
item.description: Welcome to my site!!! Brief Intro: Simon Yang Annyeonghaseyo! My name is Simon Yang and I’m from South Korea. I really enjoying traveling and scuba diving and espcially enjoy scuba diving while traveling! Apart from Korea, I have lived in the following places: United Arab Emirates Jordan Singapore Hong Kong As someone looking into investment banking, I would like to work in Canary Wharf in one of the many financial institutions located there.

item.title: Analysis on IBM's HR Practice
item.description: knitr::opts_chunk$set( message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, tidy=FALSE, # display code as typed size="small") # slightly smaller font for code options(digits = 3) # default figure size knitr::opts_chunk$set( fig.width=6.75, fig.height=6.75, fig.align = "center" ) Let’s try to figure out how IBM practices different pay practice according to employees’ roles! hr_dataset <- read_csv(here::here("data", "datasets_1067_1925_WA_Fn-UseC_-HR-Employee-Attrition.csv")) glimpse(hr_dataset) ## Rows: 1,470 ## Columns: 35 ## $ Age <dbl> 41, 49, 37, 33, 27, 32, 59, 30, 38, 36, 35.

item.title: Boris Bike Stats
item.description: knitr::opts_chunk$set( message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, tidy=FALSE, # display code as typed size="small") # slightly smaller font for code options(digits = 3) # default figure size knitr::opts_chunk$set( fig.width=6.75, fig.height=6.75, fig.align = "center" ) library(fivethirtyeight) data(drinks) glimpse(drinks) ## Rows: 193 ## Columns: 5 ## $ country <chr> "Afghanistan", "Albania", "Algeria", "... ## $ beer_servings <int> 0, 89, 25, 245, 217, 102, 193, 21, 261... ## $ spirit_servings <int> 0, 132, 0, 138, 57, 128, 25, 179, 72, .

item.title: Climate change and weather
item.description: Let’s try to find out if climate change really has been causing weather distruptions in the world! Climate change and temperature anomalies weather <- read_csv("https://data.giss.nasa.gov/gistemp/tabledata_v3/NH.Ts+dSST.csv", skip = 1, na = "***") weather_selected <- select(weather, Year:Dec) weather_selected_long <- weather_selected %>% pivot_longer(cols = 2:13, #columns 2 to 13 names_to = "Month", values_to = "delta") tidyweather <- weather_selected_long %>% mutate(date = ymd(paste(as.character(Year), Month, "1")), month = month(date, label=TRUE), year = year(date)) ggplot(tidyweather, aes(x=date, y = delta))+ geom_point()+ geom_smooth(color="red") + theme_bw() + labs ( title = "Weather Anomalies" ) Is the effect of increasing temperature more pronounced in some months?

item.title: IMDB Movie Ratings by Genre
item.description: knitr::opts_chunk$set( message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, tidy=FALSE, # display code as typed size="small") # slightly smaller font for code options(digits = 3) # default figure size knitr::opts_chunk$set( fig.width=6.75, fig.height=6.75, fig.align = "center" ) Let’s find out how ratings are diferent based on genres! movies <- read_csv(here::here("data", "movies.csv")) glimpse(movies) ## Rows: 2,961 ## Columns: 11 ## $ title <chr> "Avatar", "Titanic", "Jurassic World", "The Ave... ## $ genre <chr> "Action", "Drama", "Action", "Action", "Action".

item.title: Selected Equity Retuns on NYSE
